metadata.title: Should Autonomous Vehicles Use Context-Sensitive Ethics?
metadata.subtitle: Examining Rigid Rules vs. Adaptive Algorithms Through Utilitarian Analysis

primary.title: Primary Research Question
primary.question: Should autonomous vehicles be programmed with rigid ethical rules that treat all demographics equally (as mandated by the German Ethics Commission), or should they adapt in real-time using context-sensitive factors in unavoidable accident scenarios?

secondary.title: Secondary Research Question
secondary.question: At what levels of model accuracy and informational connectedness, if any, does context-sensitive AV decision-making become more ethically defensible than rigid demographic-blind foresight rules?

findings.title: Decision Sensitivity to Connectedness
findings.description: 67% of scenarios (4 of 6) changed recommendations based on connectedness level, demonstrating that informational connectedness is a critical policy variable that fundamentally determines which lives AVs prioritize. This sensitivity reveals that society must explicitly choose which level of connectedness to implement, as each level produces systematically different outcomes.

findings.title: Pregnancy Information Reverses Intuitive Logic
findings.description: Low connectedness (pregnancy unknown): Hit pregnant woman, save 2 people (50 vs 76 harm) - standard "save more people" logic. High connectedness (pregnancy known): Save pregnant woman, hit 2 people (90 vs 76 harm with 1.8x multiplier) - pregnancy information flips decision. The paradox: Learning she is pregnant causes the system to save FEWER people (1 instead of 2), prioritizing the weighted value of pregnancy over raw numbers. Reveals tension between "maximize people saved" vs "maximize weighted life-years." Any multiplier >1.52 produces this reversal.

findings.title: Legal Responsibility vs Equal Protection
findings.description: Legal fault weighting reduces jaywalker priority by 37% (0.9 jaywalking √ó 0.7 risky behavior = 0.63x total). Creates tension between two valid principles: (1) equal protection - all lives have equal worth regardless of minor infractions, versus (2) responsibility - those who follow rules have stronger moral claims. Extended connectedness systematically favors rule-followers.

findings.title: Occupation-Based Social Hierarchies
findings.description: Occupation and criminal history weighting transforms neutral 1v1 scenario into decisive recommendation (save doctor: 64.5 vs 40.42 harm), resolving ethical ambiguity through utilitarian calculus of secondary effects (doctor's future life-saving work vs criminal's recidivism risk). Raises analytical question: Should AVs consider individuals' social contributions and past actions when determining whom to save? Requires weighing utilitarian logic (maximize total welfare) against egalitarian principles (equal intrinsic worth regardless of occupation or history).

frameworks.name: Utilitarian
frameworks.description: Maximize overall well-being. Used in this analysis with evidence-based harm calculations.

frameworks.name: Deontological
frameworks.description: Duty-based ethics. All lives have equal intrinsic worth regardless of context.

frameworks.name: Virtue Ethics
frameworks.description: Character-based. Focuses on what a virtuous person would do in the situation.

analyticalQuestions: Should AVs consider social contributions (doctor vs criminal)?
Is it ethical to "punish" rule-breakers (jaywalkers) with death?
Does pregnancy create a moral multiplier, or should all lives be equal?
At what accuracy threshold does context-sensitive become defensible?
remainingResearch: Compare findings to MIT Moral Machine public opinion data
Expert validation from ethicists and ASPI researchers

preliminaryInsights.text: Informational connectedness is a critical policy variable that fundamentally shapes AV ethical behavior (50% of scenarios changed).
Utilitarian quantification creates value hierarchies (doctor 1.5x, criminal 0.94x, pregnancy 1.8x) that may conflict with equal human dignity.
No clear threshold exists where increased connectedness consistently improves ethical outcomes‚Äîit both resolves ambiguity AND introduces controversial results.
The choice is not technical but political: Society must explicitly decide which factors AVs should consider.
